entry.title: Cloud on the rise (Love JANET)
entry.summary:
A Modular, hybrid success story

BroadcastÂ Dr Phil Richards from Loughborough University heads into The Reg studios on October 20th at 10am (BST) to tell us how he's building modular hybrid clouds.â€¦

entry.title: This Dianamania is a slur on Jobs
entry.summary:
Let's remember him properly

OpinionÂ Steve Jobs was a remarkable and fascinating businessman, and by some distance the most interesting and accomplished personality operating in an important corner of the economy. He had a respect for the intelligence of human beings and their ambition, and potential â€“ showing an optimism which is rare in a cynical industry. And Jobs left us far too early.â€¦

entry.title: Ofcom admits 4G auction will slip
entry.summary:
More consultation aimed at placating all parties

Struggling to cope with responses to its consultation, Ofcom will refine its 4G auction proposals for the end of 2011, and seek feedback with a view to commencing in Q4 2012.â€¦

entry.title: Ellison's cloud conversion is good for business
entry.summary:
Skeptic turned evangelist to win CIOs

Open...and ShutÂ For those agnostics who continue to doubt the reality of cloud adoption, there are two clear signs: the adoption of Amazon's public cloud and Larry Ellison's public cloud creation. The first is a sign of the appetite for cloud while the latter is a suggestion that even the cloud laggards have eventually found their way to their seats. Now if someone would just tell the CIOs...â€¦

entry.title: Skye IT goes titsup
entry.summary:
Reseller hits the wall after credit dries up

Skye IT has gone into administration today after running into financial difficulties, appointing Taylor Aitken to manage the wind-down.â€¦

entry.summary:
Tweets, sites big-up world's boffins of the female persuasion

Today was Ada Lovelace Day, a day for commemorating women's contribution to science and technology, named after the woman who is widely credited as being the world's first computer programmer.â€¦

entry.title: Samsung, Micron bake 3D chips for next-gen RAM
entry.summary:
Not-particularly-cube-shaped cubes prove faster

We're hitting a memory wall, if you didn't know, and processor cores are going to be held up because DRAM can't scale up enough or ship 'em data fast enough. Samsung and Micron aim to fix that with 3D memory cubes and a consortium to define an interface spec for them.â€¦

entry.title: AmEx 'debug mode left site wide open', says hacker
entry.summary:
Customer cookies 'at risk'

An alleged vulnerability on American Express site exposed customers to a serious security risk before the credit card giant closed down a portion of its site on Thursday afternoon.â€¦

entry.title: Google hits the boozer with own brand of beer
entry.summary:
What ales thee?

Google's investments over the years have pushed the company's foot through many a door. However, its latest venture still comes as quite a surprise. The Internet tech-firm is now producing beer.â€¦

entry.title: 'Silent majority' is content with elderly Java, says startup
entry.summary:

Oracle might be looking at Java 7 and 8 to float clouds, but tech vendors are only just adopting Java 6 as a serious prop for web-based computing.â€¦

entry.title: Visa muscles into Olympic pay-by-wave with microSD kit
entry.summary:
Non-NFC gadgets to join Samsung's 2012 phone for on-site payments

Samsung's Olympic Phone won't be the only gadget able to make payments within the London venue next year, with Visa planning an operator bypass with microSD.â€¦

entry.title: Old Napster guyâ€™s fan letter to Spotify upstart
entry.summary:
'Grasshopper. You are almost as cool as I once was'

The original Napster was the greatest digital music service weâ€™ve ever seen â€“ and, into the bargain, was the first global social network. Choosing to close it, rather than financially exploit it, is something many people in the music business have regretted ever since. They had a new world of consumers in the palm of their hand, but chose to crush it.â€¦

entry.title: HP names Ubuntu top dog for OpenStack cloud
entry.summary:
Secure, scalable, "business class"

Ubuntu has been named "lead host and guest operating system" on Hewlett-Packard's fledgling OpenStack-based cloud.â€¦

entry.title: BT hauls Digital Economy Act back to court
entry.summary:
Last chance for telco to slay the beast

The Court of Appeal has today granted BT permission to appeal against the High Courtâ€™s judicial review of the Digital Economy Act. BT had attempted to get sections of the Act repealed in the High Court, but saw most of its arguments thrown out in April. It won a minor point on costs, but the five cornerstones of its argument were rejected.â€¦

entry.title: IE security hole sewn up for Patch Tuesday

Microsoft is planning eight security updates next week â€“ two critical â€“ as part of its regular Patch Tuesday programme.â€¦

entry.title: Here come hypervisors you can trust

Intel to the rescue?

Virtualisation has always bothered me. This is perhaps an odd statement to make; after all, I am personally responsible for virtualising thousands of servers.â€¦

The European Union is set to green-light Microsoft's â‚¬5.9bn acquisition of VoIP behemoth Skype, putting 145 million users under Redmond's control.â€¦

entry.title: London 2012 Olympics: 17000 athletes, 11000 computers
entry.summary:
Acer: 'It won't run on Vista like we said it would'

UpdatedÂ Even if you don't care about people running quickly around in circles, it can't have escaped your notice that the Olympics is coming to London for 17 days in July 2012. As the world's biggest sports event of the year, it will involve 17,000 athletes, 20,000 members of the press, millions of spectators (10 million tickets sold - more to come), billions of people watching on television. And a lot of computers.â€¦

entry.title: Google Books app splurts 3 million titles in UK launch
entry.summary:
Book-grabber faces off with Kindle and iBooks in Blighty

Android users will be able to browse 3 million books on their phones, after Google Books launched in the UK yesterday.â€¦

entry.title: El Reg drives Cloud Summit

EventÂ On December 5, London's increasingly popular annual Business Cloud Summit features a Technology and Developer stream helmed by The Registerâ€™s own Tim Phillips. For you, dear reader, that means finely tuned, guff-free content.â€¦

entry.title: Sony tempts Potter fans with free 3D BDs
entry.summary:
Buy a Sony player, get Deathly Hallows discs

Desperate to flog some 3D gear, Sony is to give away copies of the last to Harry Potter films - the Deathly Hallows pair - to entice punters to part with cash for one of its 3D BD players.â€¦

entry.title: Cambridge Audio iD100 hi-fi dock
entry.summary:
Digital-only interface for audiophiles

ReviewÂ The Cambridge Audio iD100 is a dock with apparent delusions of grandeur. Brushed aluminium bodywork and a surfeit of serious connectivity signal a determination to squeeze every last drop of performance from any iOS device that comes its way.â€¨â€¨ Clearly it takes the music on my iPod far more seriously than I do.â€¦

entry.title: HP denies shipping TouchPad tablets with Android

Probe launched

HP is investigating why an unknown number of TouchPad WebOS tablets may have been sold with Android on board.â€¦

entry.title: ISPs must be honest to keep net neutrality alive, say watchdogs
entry.summary:
Being transparent is now a good thing

Providing consumers with transparent information about the quality and restrictiveness of their internet service is "fundamental" if net neutrality it to be achieved, European telecoms regulators have said.â€¦

entry.title: Quote of the Week: 'I shave my balls for this?'
entry.summary:
Our weekly round-up of what the tech world says

QuoTWÂ This was the week when Apple cofounder and technology titan Steve Jobs sadly passed away, aspiring geeks were told they shouldn't bother leaving their bedrooms to go to school, Amazon's decision to lose money on the Kindle Fire made good business sense, overzealous Microsoft anti-virus software classed Google's Chrome browser as malware and someone released some sort of new smartphone.â€¦

entry.title: IBM attracts Crocus to magnetic RAM biz
entry.summary:
Big Blue wants stiffer poles

IBM has drafted in Crocus Technology in hope of blossoming its long-running MRAM flash follow-on technology effort. Where this leaves Big Blue's racetrack memory effort is unclear.â€¦

entry.title: TomTom ties up traffic with Top Gear
entry.summary:
MORE POWER, insists Clarkson-voiced satnav

It had to happen - it's just surprising it has taken this long. Yes, a satnav company - TomTom in this case - has launched a TopGear-branded unit.â€¦

entry.title: Open Range rural broadband goes titsup
entry.summary:
WiMAX on satellite frequencies â€“ what could possibly go wrong?

Despite tapping the US government for cash and promising to connect six million people, Open Range has called it a day, laying off most of the staff and filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy.â€¦

entry.title: TDK fires up LASERS to double hard drive capacity
entry.summary:
HAMR blow to disk heads

Japanese disk drive head supplier TDK says it has added a laser heater to its platter licking devices to enable heat-assisted magnetic recording. In non-boffinry speak, this will double disk drives' areal density - and therefore double capacity. All suppliers have to do is come up with the right chemical mix for the platters.â€¦

entry.title: MoJ shops for ICT provider for Her Majesty's prisons
entry.summary:
3-year deal to give services to crim-managers

The Ministry of Justice (MoJ) is looking for a provider of ICT services for the National Offender Management Service (Noms), as part of a transition towards using its Future ICT Sourcing (Fits) model.â€¦

entry.title: Mixing network traffic types on Ethernet
entry.summary:
A recipe for success - or disaster?

Expert ClinicÂ Is Fibre Channel over Ethernet (FCoE) a panacea for the difficulties inherent in running separate storage and general networks?â€¦

entry.title: Panasonic HM-TA20 underwater camcorder
entry.summary:
Taking a dip

ReviewÂ Pocket camcorders might have lost their appeal since the spread of HD-ready smartphones but the amphibious nature of the Panasonic HM-TA20 is still likely to grab the attention of holidaymakers. The HM-TA20 is an underwater pocket camcorder capable of shooting 1080p videos and 8Mp still images up to depth of 3m and also doubles up as a digital voice recorder, with a number of ad hoc options.â€¦

entry.title: Intellectual Ventures wages patent war on Motorola
entry.summary:
Claims 6 infringements of its property

Intellectual Ventures, the patent holding firm set up by former Microsoft Chief Technical Officer Nathan Myhrvold, has filed suit against Motorola for patent infringement.â€¦

entry.title: Chaos feared after Unix time-zone database is nuked
entry.summary:
Developer sued for copyright infringement

The internet's authoritative source for time-zone data has been shut down after the volunteer programmer who maintained it was sued for copyright infringement by a maker of astrology software.â€¦

entry.summary:
Junior telco plots Oz fibre upgrade

Primus Australia has announced the start of a rollout that it hopes will eventually reach five Australian mainland capital cities.â€¦

entry.title: Pay to watch free stuff on Xbox 360
entry.summary:
An offer too good to refuse

There are many characteristics about Australia that people from other countries donâ€™t get: dangerous animals, a big empty country, political angst over an economy that stubbornly fails to plunge into recession, and so on. But two Iâ€™d like to single out here are TV and the Internet.â€¦

entry.title: Can general relativity explain the OPERA neutrino result?
entry.summary:
Imperial College physicist looks at gravitational time effects

CERNâ€™s decision to release data about its â€œsuperluminal neutrinoâ€ experiments at an early stage is providing the world with a rare insight into the process of scientific peer review. Another small step in that process in relation to the fascinating OPERA results asks whether general relativity can be called in to help explain the results.â€¦

entry.title: Gay-bashing cult plans picket of Steve Jobs funeral
entry.summary:
Tweets the news via an iPhone in irony fail

Members of the Westboro Baptist Church (WBC) have announced their intention to protest at the funeral of Steve Jobs, in a Twitter message sent via an iPhone.â€¦
